repnme.cdata!:
India - Industrial Pollution Control
            Project and Industrial Pollution Prevention Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the India Industrial
            Pollution Control Project were as follows: Outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory; sustainability was likely; Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. The ratings for the India Industrial
            Pollution Prevention Project were as follows: Outcome was
            moderately unsatisfactory; sustainability was likely; Bank
            performance was unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. Lessons learned included: 1) The Bank should
            not go forward with new (even complementary follow-on)
            projects that attempt to extend and/or replicate previously
            untested design approaches when there has been insufficient
            opportunity to monitor, evaluate and learn from the
            implementation experience and results of the first
            operation. Adequate monitoring and evaluation mechanisms are
            also particularly important under these circumstances; 2) to
            the extent possible the objectives of Bank-supported
            environment projects should identify upfront the specific
            outcomes they seek to achieve in terns of improvements in
            environmental quality; 3) efforts should have been placed in
            the context of more comprehensive national and local
            pollution abatement strategies, involving the full range of
            contributing sectors (in all likelihood including urban
            sanitation, transport, energy and even agriculture, as well
            as industry) and suitable actions to address air, water and
            land degradation problems in a more spatially focused way;
            4) project environmental outcomes may not have had a
            significant impact in terns of improving overall ambient air
            and water quality in the places where these industrial
            plants are situated; 5) it is impossible to determine the
            relative priority of addressing industrial, as compared with
            other, sources of pollution at any particular locality, or
            more generally. This should, in fact, have been the starting
            point for Bank involvement in this regard; 6) by not taking
            an area-based approach to addressing pollution problems, the
            Bank missed an opportunity to implement one of its own
            specific recommendations following its assessment of
            Government of India's Environment Action Program in
            1995; 7) the approach to industrial pollution management
            through Industrial Pollution Control Project and Industrial
            Pollution Prevention Project was also a partial one in that
            it did not incorporate the full range of instruments which
            could have potentially been used to achieve pollution
            prevention and control objectives; and 8) in project
            extension decisions, development effectiveness
            considerations should take precedence over internal Bank
            portfolio quality concerns.

7628128.trustfund:
TF022622-PHRD-INDUSTRIAL POLLUTION
            CONTROL II PROJ.,TF026740-INDUSTRIAL ENVIRONMENT PROJECT,TF023590-NETHERLANDS -TAGPE-ENVIRONMENT,TF031486-ASIA REGION - ENVIRONMENT,TF031488-ASIA REGION - ENVIRONMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome showed mixed
            results: overall, physical objectives were satisfactorily
            met, but its environmental performance was unsatisfactory,
            and sustainability is unlikely. Excessively broad investment
            eligibility criteria, poorly designed interest rate
            covenant, and lack of interest rate subsidy reporting during
            implementation, contributed to a marginal Bank performance,
            coupled with the failure to incorporate sludge disposal in
            subproject design. Regardless of the borrower's
            satisfactory counterpart funding, inadequate procurement,
            and project coordination/management practices were
            nonetheless unsatisfactory. The key lessons convey that
            institutional strengthening, and technical assistance
            components, should complement the investment component,
            along with an agreed implementation program, in place at the
            preparation stage. In addition, procurement of equipment
            should be decentralized to beneficiaries, which
            incidentally, local World Bank offices, have already,
            delegated these responsibilities accordingly. To ensure
            effluents sustainability, a model should be developed - to
            contain pollution - in accordance with adequate design,
            scope, management, and ownership issues, as well as cost
            sharing systems. Since environmental credit lines rarely
            contribute to successful outcomes, well designed technical
            assistance, and institutional building, should prod
            environmental performance.

18152629.subsc: Sub-natl govt admin,Gen wat/san/fld sect,Banking,Central government administration,Trade
18152629.theme: Pollution management and environmental health,Environmental policies and institutions
18152629.trustfund:
TF026740-INDUSTRIAL ENVIRONMENT PROJECT,TF022622-PHRD-INDUSTRIAL POLLUTION
            CONTROL II PROJ.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objective is to
            support the Government of India's efforts to prevent
            and alleviate environmental degradation caused by industrial
            operations and assist in the successful attainment of the
            proposed short and medium-term targets of its environmental
            policy. The project is designed to assist in the
            identification and implementation of a cost effective
            program for industrial pollution monitoring, control, and
            abatement within the context of institutional and financial
            constraints present in India. The project comprises three
            components: (1) an institutional component designed to
            strengthen the Central and State Pollution Control Boards in
            the states of Gujarat, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and Uttar
            Pradesh; (2) an investment component designed to support
            efforts by industry to comply with regulations, including
            the support for the set up of common treatment facilities;
            and (3) a technical assistance component designed to support
            the Ministry of Environment and the DFI's to provide
            specialized technical assistance for the evaluation of
            environmental problems and the assessment of their solutions.
